So what did I do over my winter holidays?

[spoiler]I solved a crime, almost got shot by a tank, went to Comicon, defended the school from a fanboy-powered laser cannon, saw a lunar eclipse, almost went into a coma, fought a psychotic post-humous Hydra bird, read some stories and visited the local shrine. Also,[/spoiler] I played Team Fortress 2. Also played Hatoful Boyfriend: Holiday Star.

This is a visual novel game, being more on the "novel" end of the spectrum with all the reading involved. There are still opportunities to make decisions, and said decisions can still have consequences. So make sure you save when you need to. 
There are 4 main episodes, with about 6 mini-episodes and about 6 radio episodes. Each are fairly independent from each other, though there are some occasional small references to other episodes. I also find that the game makes some rather obscure references to Japanese culture, birds and the visual novel genre itself, so it helps to have an internet browser open to look up anything weird you come across like "manyoshu" or "moe". 

The storyline is as ridiculous as you would expect it to be, especially with the introduction of Miru+Kaku (comedy relief), Tohri [spoiler](self-proclaimed villain?)[/spoiler] and The King [spoiler](the true villain!)[/spoiler]. Much like the first game, things start off with a simple plot, and then escalates to a bigger scheme and then finishes with a final punchline. 
Sometimes the main episodes can feel longer than you'd expected, and I think it took me about 15 to 30 minutes per episode, since I try to read the story and all.
I liked the Picture Book sections in the last two episodes. They can be rather abstract stories, but really set the transition well for the last episode because of the tone used and the stakes in the storyline at those key moments.
The last episode was certainly a real gut buster. Not only because of the inherent shift in storyline tone, but also because of the feels that each character struggles with and how to overcome themselves. I mean, I sort of felt bad for The King at that point of the story, but you know enough of the truth by then.

The mini-episodes are tremendously shorter than the main episodes. They revolve around little non-canonical adventures, like Legumentines with Okosan, and the Kyoto field trip. Nothing too serious but still moderately entertaining, sort of like the filler episodes from your favourite anime show. 

The radio episodes are essentially Q&A sessions with Ryouta and other characters to answer fan mail...apparently. Some of the episodes reference the secret BBL ending of the first game, so be aware of that. Otherwise, nothing too serious there and moderately entertaining.

The music is nice, I still can't believe Yuuya gets his own theme played whenever he enters the scene. It's a groovy tune, admittedly. Sound is used occasionally, and is usualy just for simple things like plates being smashed or Okosan running off. 

Achievements are fairly easy. Just watch the episodes and their variants, and that's basically that. 

In conclusion, I'd say this is a good 9/10.
It would help to have an autosave feature after certain segments of the story so I don't have to skip through everything [i]again[/i]. Also, I miss the option to have human versions of the characters (this is only available in the Shrine Visit mini-episode).

It doesn't follow the typical branching-path format of visual novels like the first game; rather, Holiday Star has a main menu with many options, which take you to the four core stories and some shorter bonus stories. [i] Holiday Star [/i] is the not-quite-a-sequel, not-quite-a-prequel to [i] Hatoful Boyfriend, [/i] the infamous “pigeon dating simulator” that turned out to be so much more than just a lulz-y joke.  It takes place in an alternate timeline from the previous game (ignoring the events of what [i] Hatoful [/i] players call “the BBL route”), and assumes that the player already has some basic familiarity with the characters.

Most notably from a gameplay perspective, [i] Holiday Star [/i] abandons the dating-sim structure of [i] Hatoful Boyfriend [/i] in favor of a straightforward visual-novel approach.  The player is given a few choices to make over the course of the game, but most of these either advance the plot or result in insta-death, rendering the choices essentially false.  In other words, it’s basically what fans of the genre call a “kinetic” (i.e. choice-less) story.  This is a game for people who love the characters of [i] Hatoful Boyfriend [/i] and just want to tag along with them on some silly holiday-themed adventures, rather than control the story from the driver’s seat.

I use the word “silly” deliberately.  Although there are a few genuinely touching moments (a conversation between Ryouta and Yuuya about love and the possibility of rejection comes to mind), most of the game is taken up with deliberately absurd, even surreal humor.  For example, in one chapter the nefarious villain (a flamboyant scientist with a score to settle) tries to destroy St. PigeoNation’s Academy by blasting it with a cannon powered by female manga nerds. ("I have heard that the fantasies of fangirls surpass those of any fanboy. Observe, and be destroyed!").  There’s also plenty of fourth wall-breaking moments, including radio interludes where the characters respond to questions from real-life fans of the series about their taste in underwear, etc.  [i] Macbeth, [/i] this ain’t.

Cynics might say that the developer just wanted to milk [i] Hatoful Boyfriend’s [/i] surprising success for more money, but I disagree.  [i] Holiday Star [/i] feels like it was made with genuine affection and inspiration. Hatoful Boyfriend es el simulador de citas con palomas por excelencia, o mas bien el único. Tuvo tanta repercusión y éxito por allá en el 2011 que los desarrolladores decidieron realizar una nueva versión para las fiestas. No se trata de un DLC ni nada por el estilo, sino mas bien un juego aparte y en plena epoca navideña paso a comentártelo.


El juego se divide en cuatro episodios y una serie de capítulos extra mas cortos, además de otros extras que simulan ser un programa radial conducido por las mismas palomas y están referidos a la historia del juego.

Al comienzo de cada episodio tenemos la posibilidad de elegir nuestro nombre y apellido, que es el que utilizarán el resto de los personajes para referirse a nosotros. Podemos tener diferentes nombres en cada uno de los capítulos ya que no afecta la experiencia de juego.

Sin spoilearte nada te cuento que le primer episodio se centra en las festividades navideñas y nosotros, unos simples humanos, junto con otras palomas, tenemos que descubrir quiénes son los ladrones de la Navidad que se están robando los árboles del vecindario y del instituto al cual aparentemente concurrimos. El segundo se aleja un poco del espíritu navideño y nos sitúa en una convención de manga y animé en la cual tenemos que evitar que nuestro amigo paloma se involucre en la edición de su manga con un villano que planea destruir todo con su rayo laser *inserte gif de Monsters Inc.*. El tercer y cuarto episodio están enlazados y transcurren en un sueño que todas las palomas tienen en conjunto.


Si aún no te diste cuenta lo bizarro que es desde el título, también hay tanques de guerra, rayos laser como mencioné anteriormente y algunos otros artefactos propios de un villano de película como para darle vida a la historia, la cual no es tan divertida como parece.

Siendo un “juego” estilo visual novel no está muy bien realizado ya que en cada uno de los capítulos tenemos solo una oportunidad en la cual elegir una opción que cambie el resto de la historia, por lo tanto se torna aburrido y pesado esperar hasta ese momento para ver si nuestra opción es la adecuada o no.


Otro factor que juega en contra es la calidad visual de los pájaros. Se ven pixelados, y si bien no es un juego en donde los gráficos tengan que ser excepcionales, molesta estar jugando con tu personaje en una calidad más baja que la escena de fondo.

A todo esto, si le vemos el lado positivo podemos rescatar la personalidad de las aves. No solo hay palomas, sino también hay otro tipo de pájaros similares y no tanto, que se diferencian por sus plumajes.
